analytic.title: The Development of Testimony Collections in Early Christian Apologetics with Islam

biblStruct.note: Examines the Arabic Version of the “Apology of Patriarch Timothy I”, the anonymous “On the Triune Nature of God” (MS Sinai Arabic 154), and the “Debate of Theodore Abū Qurra at the Court of al-Maʾmūn”. The author argues that Arabic testimony collections served as “theological manuals for apologists”. Accordingly, they stand in the tradition of earlier Greek and Latin testimonia but take a shape of their own since they were fashioned to answer new challenges. Not the burgeoning translations of the Bible into Arabic but the Qurʾān is the driving force behind the compilation of testimony collections.

analytic.title: Some Remarks on the Biblical Quotations in Abū Qurrah’s Tract On the Veneration of the Holy Icons

biblStruct.note: Investigates translation technique of biblical quotations in Theodore’s “On Icon Veneration”. The author’s findings are that Theodore (mostly) used the Septuagint as his Vorlage. Still, the quotations betray “traces of Aramaic influence”. There are certain similarities between Theodore’s quotations and the Bible translations of the Qaraites in Jerusalem.

analytic.title: Notes sur les citations bibliques chez Abū Qurrah

biblStruct.note: The author holds that Theodore quoted from memory and did not have a fixed Arabic translation at his disposal. Moreover, he comes to the following conclusions: The quotations betray Syriac influence. Contrary to his Arabic writings, in his Greek works Theodore sticks to the wording of the Biblical texts. He does not view the text of the Bible as revealed Scripture in the Qurʾānic sense. The quotations do not exclude that Theodore might have authored the “Summa theologiae arabica” (MS London, British Library, Or. 4950).

analytic.title: Ammār al-Baṣrī on the alleged corruption of the Gospels

biblStruct.note: The author argues that ʿAmmār mainly employs reductio ad absurdum arguments to render void the allegation of falsification of the Gospels (taḥrīf). His arguments display a “post-Enlightenment quality” in that he appeals to psychology and historicity. ʿAmmār deals with both the charges of alteration (taḥrīf al-naṣṣ) and misinterpretation (taḥrīf al-maʿnā). According to the author, the former was the more pressing issue. Al-Qāsim ibn Ibrāhīm’s Refutation of the Christians is used as a Muslim comparative text to ʿAmmār.

monogr.title: Les manuscrits arabes des lettres de Paul. La reprise d'un champ de recherche négligé.

biblStruct.note: The Arabic translations of the New Testament are an important phenomenon following the spread of the Islam and the arrival and institutionalization of the Arabic language. This is attested by a great number of manuscripts. Despite this, very little research was conducted in this field since the beginning of the 20th century. However, a renewed interest can be observed today for these manuscripts, related to contemporary identity issues and the emergence of the digital culture. In this thesis, I analyse the reasons of this lack of interest and contribute to the current scholarly rediscovery by studying the largely unexplored corpus of the Arabic manuscripts of the Letters of Paul. I propose a catalogue of the Arabic manuscripts of the Letters of Paul. After that, I focus on a specific manuscript from the 9th century, the Vaticanus Arabicus 13, with the edition of the First Letter to the Corinthians and the study of its linguistic and philological aspects. I also show its theological interest by underlining interesting exegetical points

biblStruct.note: This article examines the text of an Arabic Gospel manuscript from the "New Finds" at St. Catherine's Monastery, Sinai. It provides a general description of the codex, and then studies two hundred and thirty readings in Saint Luke's Gospel. These readings differ from the Majority Text and agree with some of the earliest Greek witnesses as well as ancient versions. The contribution of this manuscript is shown to be considerable, and a warning against minimizing the textual value of the Arabic versions.

monogr.title: The Arabic Versions of the Gospels: the Manuscripts and Their Families.
The Arabic Versions of the Gospels

biblStruct.note: This book pertains to the early Arabic translations of the canonical Gospels, and is based on extensive research in over two hundred manuscripts, copied between the eighth and the nineteenth centuries. The manuscripts were collated from twenty-one different library collections in Europe and the Orient. Each individual manuscript was examined and subsequently grouped into twenty-four families. The Arabic manuscripts were originally translated from Greek, Syriac, Coptic, or Latin. This foundational work is an invaluable resource for those seeking to learn more about the Arab Christian heritage, t.

monogr.title: Epistola Pauli ad Galatas: item sex primaria capita christianae religionis, Arabice : Quitus ad finem adjunctum est Compendium Grammatias Arabice, authore Ruthgero Spey : Addita quoque est interpretation Latina ad verbum (eodem authore) reddita
Epistola Pauli ad Galatas

biblStruct.note: Woodcut, Epistle to the Galatians in Arabic and Latin; edited by Rutgher Spey from an Arabic Ms. at the Palatine Library, Heidelberg. Today it is preserved as Vatican, BAV, 23. analytic.title: Die arabischen Handschriften des Neuen Testaments in der zeitgenössischen Forschung: ein Überblick
Die arabischen Handschriften des Neuen Testaments in der zeitgenössischen Forschung

biblStruct.note: This article offers an overview about the state of research in the field of the Arabic Manuscripts of the New Testament. It critically analyzes the lack of the Western research in these manuscripts, which is an object of research falling between the discipline of the New Testament textual criticism and the Orientalist studies. In this background it provides an account for the different identity questions surrounding these manuscripts and integrates them in the new discourse productions, which the Internet and the digital age facilitate.
